Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Disentangling the influence of functional similarity on patterns of species abundance in tree communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests harbor a remarkable level of biodiversity characterized by an exceptional number of rare species and few dominant species. Human and natural disturbances are increasingly threatening the condition of these forests and with it, their benefits to human well-being. Disentangling the causes of species relative abundance constitutes a critical step in order to protect, maintain and predict the fate of biodiversity. By studying within-species trait variation and individual growth of 650 individual trees from six species broadly distributed throughout Puerto Rico, this project will determine how functional traits influence tree species diversity. The resulting insights from this research will help to foster decisions devoted to preventing biodiversity loss in tropical forests. Further, this project will support training for science students as well as outreach efforts via public talks encouraging young people to pursue career in tropical ecology.

Identifying the ecological forces that underlie species relative abundances has been a lingering challenging in ecology. One potential explanation for this pattern is based on the idea that species have differential abilities to exploit resources heterogeneously distributed in the space and time. This ability is expected to be strongly associated with different attributes that affect the performance of individuals and ultimately their distribution and abundance. This study focuses on understanding how organismal traits influence patterns of species relative abundance. The relationship between organismal function and performance will be evaluated using in a spatially explicit context. Methods will include measuring the growth and traits of individual trees for six species distributed along an altitudinal gradient in Puerto Rico. The proposed research will expand our knowledge of the ecological mechanisms underlying patterns of species relative abundance by considering not only species identities but also trait information. Results from this project will have direct implications for natural resource management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This project focused on understanding the role of organismal traits influencing patterns of performance (i.e. tree growth) and ultimately driving the patterns of species relative abundance in tropical tree communities. Although, species are usually broadly distributed across several environments, exhibiting fluctuating abundances, few studies have examined the variation in organismal traits a performance along broad spatial scales. Through this research, I have been monitoring diameter growth of more than 600 trees of six tree species distributed along an elevational gradient that goes from 250 m.a.s.l (meters above sea level) to 1000 m.a.s.l in Puerto Rico. I have also collected several leaf and wood organismal traits of all individuals that would inform about the ecological strategies (i.e. photosynthetic capacity and mechanical stability-water transport efficiency) of these trees.

The results of this project yielded a significant understanding of the links between trait variations and growth rates for broadly distributed species. For example, leaf traits exhibit significant variation across environmental gradients, indicating that species are able to track the environment in order to fit local conditions. However, growth patterns did not show similar trends, suggesting that performance outcomes (i.e. growth) may be invariant across much of the range of a species due to systematic variation in organ-level traits along the same gradient. In addition, our/my data shows that, despite the broad trait variation within species, trait distribution peak in particular trait values, suggesting that species have single optimal strategies, instead of multiple peaks, where traits are likely more efficient to acquire resources. 

Broader of impacts: The main broader impact of this project was my training.  This fellowship allowed me to enhance my natural history skills in the field as well as to develop statistical and computational skills to analyze the data. In addition, this project contributed to training an undergraduate student in the identification of tropical tree species, dendrometer installation and monitoring as well as trait data collection. This project has also contributed to providing information on performance and trait variation of species broadly distributed along environmental gradients that will be useful for forest management on biodiversity conservation projects.

Research products: This project has generated one manuscript that in under co-authors revision and another manuscript is in preparation. Other publications are also expected from this project. After publication, the data on tree growth and functional traits will be available on Dryad Digital Repository.
